quiz.title: Unit 1, Quiz 2: Opportunity Cost & Production Possibilities
quiz.subtitle: Foundations of Macroeconomics
quiz.subject: AP Macroeconomics

questions.question: Scarcity forces individuals and societies to
questions.explanation: Scarcity means unlimited wants but limited resources, requiring choices and trade-offs.

questions.question: Opportunity cost is defined as the
options: Total financial cost of a decision
Value of the next best alternative given up
Price paid for a good or service
Cost of producing one more unit
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the best alternative sacrificed when a choice is made.

questions.question: If you choose to study for 3 hours instead of working at a job that pays $15 per hour, the opportunity cost of studying is
options: The wage plus the cost of books
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost = 3 hours × $15/hour = $45 of forgone earnings.

questions.question: A production possibilities curve (PPC) illustrates
options: The relationship between price and quantity supplied
The maximum combinations of two goods an economy can produce
The profit-maximizing output for a firm
questions.explanation: The PPC shows the maximum attainable output combinations given resources and technology.

questions.question: Points on the PPC represent
questions.explanation: Points on the curve are both attainable and efficient—resources are fully employed.

questions.question: Points inside the PPC indicate
options: The economy is producing at maximum capacity
questions.explanation: Inside the curve = resources underutilized or unemployed.

questions.question: Points outside the PPC are
questions.explanation: Outside the curve = unattainable with current resources/technology.

questions.question: If an economy must give up 8 units of good Y to produce 2 units of good X, the opportunity cost of 1 unit of X is
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost per unit X = 8Y / 2X = 4Y.

questions.question: A straight-line PPC implies
questions.explanation: Linear PPC means resources are perfectly adaptable—opportunity cost stays constant.

questions.question: A bowed-out (concave) PPC reflects
questions.explanation: Bowed-out shape = increasing opportunity costs because resources are not equally suited to both goods.

questions.question: The law of increasing opportunity cost exists because
options: Resources are not equally productive in all uses
questions.explanation: As production of one good increases, resources less suited to that good must be used, raising opportunity cost.

questions.question: Economic growth is shown on a PPC as
options: Movement from inside the curve to the curve
A shift of the curve outward
A shift of the curve inward
A change in the slope of the curve
questions.explanation: Growth expands productive capacity, shifting PPC outward.

questions.question: Which of the following would shift the PPC outward?
options: A reallocation from consumer to capital goods
An increase in the labor force
questions.explanation: More resources (labor, capital) or better technology shift PPC outward.

questions.question: If a country chooses to produce more capital goods and fewer consumer goods, its future PPC will likely
questions.explanation: Investing in capital goods increases future productive capacity, shifting PPC outward faster.

questions.question: A nation that produces only consumer goods and no capital goods will likely experience
options: A shift of the PPC inward over time
questions.explanation: Neglecting capital investment reduces future capacity—PPC may shift inward due to depreciation/obsolescence.

questions.question: The opportunity cost of producing more pizzas and fewer robots is the
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost = value of forgone robots when resources are shifted to pizza.

questions.question: If resources are specialized, the PPC will be
questions.explanation: Specialized resources → increasing opportunity costs → bowed-out PPC.

questions.question: A point on the PPC moving toward more of one good involves
options: A trade-off of less of the other good
questions.explanation: Moving along the curve = reallocating resources → more of one good, less of the other.

questions.question: If the PPC shifts inward, this could be caused by
options: An increase in the labor force
questions.explanation: Inward shift = loss of resources or decline in technology (e.g., disaster, war, pandemic).

questions.question: The concept of trade-offs is most directly illustrated by the
questions.explanation: The PPC visually demonstrates trade-offs: producing more of one good requires producing less of another.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent command of scarcity, opportunity cost, and PPC analysis.
scoreMessages.70: Solid understanding; review opportunity cost calculations and PPC shifts.
scoreMessages.50: Needs focus on PPC shapes and trade-offs.
scoreMessages.0: Revisit: scarcity, opportunity cost definition, PPC basics.
